awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Ohio River Analysis Meetings 2017-2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides three years of funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Ohio River Analysis Meetings (ORAM) 2017-2019," the first event of which will be held March 25-26, 2017, on the campus of the University of Cincinnati. The 2018 meeting will take place in Spring 2018 at the University of Kentucky, and the meeting will return to the University of Cincinnati in Spring 2019. For additional information consult the conference website: https://math.uc.edu/ORAM.

The goal of this annual regional conference series, entering its seventh year in 2017, is to stimulate scientific exchange and to foster the area of analysis in general, and the field of partial differential equations in particular. The meetings feature invited lectures by distinguished mathematicians and parallel sessions for contributed talks, mostly by early-career mathematicians. Anticipated plenary speakers for the 2017 event include the following: Alex Iosevich, Andrea Nahmod, Stefanie Petermichl, Christopher Sogge, and Jeremy Tyson.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
NSF DMS-1700277 was a three-year collaborative grant with the University of Cincinnati (UC) DMS-1700077, to support the Ohio River Analysis Meetings (ORAM) in the years of 2017, 2018, and 2019. UC was awarded funds for two years ($28,000), 2017, in which they hosted ORAM 7, and 2019, in which they hosted ORAM 9. The University of Kentucky (UK) was awarded funds ($14,000) for ORAM 8, that they hosted in 2018. These funds were for participant support at these meetings. The host institutions generously provided additional financial support.

The ORAM meetings consist of 5 one-hour talks presented by leading researchers in the fields of analysis and partial differential equations. In addition, there are 20 minute contributed talks. From the beginning, the organizing committee has given priority to early-career researchers. The ORAM meetings have become known for their support of, and highlighting of, early-career mathematicians working in analysis and partial differential equations from universities in the Ohio valley and beyond. The organizing committee also strives to increase participation of mathematicians from underrepresented groups.  ORAM meetings are held in cooperation with the Association for Women in Mathematics.  

There were 5 invited speakers at each ORAM 7, 8, and 9, for a total of 9 men and 6 women. DMS-1700277 was the primary source of funding for ORAM 8 held at UK in March 2018. This meeting had 72 participants from17 states, DC, and Canada. The 43 early-career mathematicians made up one-half of the participants and gave the majority of the contributed talks. This meeting had a larger participation by mathematicians from underrepresented groups than ORAM 7. About 25% of the contributed talks where by these mathematicians. 

ORAM 9 was held in March 2019 and was hosted by UC. About one-third of the remaing funds in DMS-1700277(about $3,000), were used to support the participation of graduate students and faculty from UK in ORAM 9.  

COVID disrupted the next ORAM meetings. ORAM 10, scheduled for March 2020 at UK, was canceled. UK hosted ORAM 10 virtually in March 2021.  The meeting was smaller with about 55 participants, but still went well. UK then hosted ORAM 11 in person in April 2022. The remaining funds from DMS-1700277 (about $1,600) were used to support ORAM 11 participants. The main funding for ORAM 11 came from DMS-2000250. The organizing committee thanks the NSF for authorizing no-cost extensions until January 31, 2023, in order to make this possible. 

The ORAM meetings have continued to provide a forum for early-career mathematicians to lear of recent developments from experts, and to present their research before an interested and distinguished audience. The organizing committee strives to ensure that early career mathematicians are financially supported so that they may participate in the meetings. The financial support of the NSF is crucial for achieving this goal. 

 


Last Modified: 07/10/2023
Modified by: Peter D Hislop
